steps.title: Launch Invoify app
details: All three test flows successfully loaded https://invoify.vercel.app in a new browser tab.

steps.title: Invoice Wizard – Bill From section should appear (Step 1)
details: The UI never exposed an element that matched the text selector “Bill From :”.
Automation timed-out after 5 s, so the remaining Bill From interactions (field entry, validation, persistence) never executed.

steps.title: Invoice Wizard – Bill To section should appear (Step 1)
details: Similar to Bill From, the expected heading “Bill To :” was not rendered/detected within 5 s, stopping the rest of the Bill To test path.

steps.title: Landing page main interface / header visibility
details: Template-selection flow expected a header reading “BETA English Toggle theme”. No such element became visible within 5 s.

steps.title: UI micro-copy & visual audit (automatic)
details: Spell-checking & content-placement: Placeholder text flagged as not informative.
Visual consistency: Button sizes & styles vary across templates.

emotional_arc: The user starts confident when the site loads, but quickly hits a wall—core wizard sections do not appear, creating confusion (“Is something broken or am I in the wrong place?”). Repeated 5-second stalls lead to frustration and abandonment. Minor visual/copy issues further erode trust, but the dominant feeling is blockage rather than polish.

qualitative_opportunities.area: Wizard entry point (Bill From / Bill To visibility)
qualitative_opportunities.why_it_matters: If first-step headings aren’t rendered or are hidden off-screen, users cannot start an invoice—this is a hard stop that drives abandonment.
next_actions: Ensure the wizard automatically opens on Step 1 when the page loads.
Use persistent, semantic headings (<h4 Bill From>) so both humans and assistive tech can locate sections.
Add skeleton loaders or progress indicators if data is still loading.

qualitative_opportunities.why_it_matters: 5-second blank states feel broken; users will refresh or leave.
next_actions: Audit network requests & lazy-loading strategy for the wizard component.
Defer non-critical scripts to prioritise first meaningful paint.
Set a generous server-side timeout fallback that shows helpful messaging (“Still loading…”) rather than nothing.

qualitative_opportunities.why_it_matters: Uninformative placeholders reduce form-fill accuracy and perceived professionalism.
next_actions: Replace lorem/blank placeholders with concrete examples (e.g., “ACME Corp, 123 Main St”).
Run a content style-guide check for each input.

qualitative_opportunities.why_it_matters: Inconsistent button sizing colours makes the product look unpolished and damages trust.
next_actions: Adopt a design-tokens system or component library to standardise button variants.
Audit existing templates for rogue CSS overrides.

qualitative_opportunities.why_it_matters: Fragile selectors break E2E tests and can hint at equally fragile accessibility semantics.
next_actions: Add data-testids or aria-labels to critical elements (wizard headings, navigation buttons).
Run an a11y audit (e.g., axe) to ensure correct landmark and heading structure.

first_tackles.description: Guarantee the wizard opens on Step 1 with visible, semantically tagged Bill From and Bill To headings.
Add clear loading state or increase initial render performance to avoid 5-second blank screen.
Introduce stable data-testids/aria-labels for key elements to unblock automation and improve accessibility.
Replace generic placeholder text with real-world examples for all form fields.
Apply a unified button component across templates to fix visual inconsistency quickly.
